page.title: 01A VILLAGE FACING NORTH-WEST
page.content: Dormansland, established as a village for over 100 years, lies pleasantly on Wealden clay and sandstone between the North Downs and the Ashdown Forest ridge. Situated halfway between London and the coast, it has four pubs, two churches - Anglican and Baptist - a post office and three village stores, an R.C. teaching convent and a residential hospital school for epilectic children, the biggest in Europe. There are also recently built private houses and two local authority housing estates, with additional accommodation for the elderly. The population of around 1750 is a good mix of young, middle-aged and old. While some commute to London, others work on farms or as home-helps or in shops; some teach, nurse, work in offices or local government and a small number are retired. The younger
